charts.title: Money Supply
charts.subtitle: M2 to GDP ratio, percent
charts.description: M2 measures the money supply including cash, checking deposits, savings deposits, and money market funds. This chart shows M2 as a share of nominal GDP.

charts.title: Real GDP per Capita
charts.subtitle: USD, in thousands
charts.description: Real GDP per capita divides inflation-adjusted gross domestic product by population. It is a broad measure of average economic output per person.

charts.title: Federal Funds Rate
charts.subtitle: Effective rate, percent
charts.description: The federal funds rate is the interest rate at which banks lend reserves to each other overnight. It is the Federal Reserve's primary tool for conducting monetary policy.

charts.title: Productivity, Selected Countries
charts.subtitle: GDP per hour of work, 2023
charts.description: Labor productivity measures GDP per hour worked, reflecting how efficiently an economy converts labor into output. Higher productivity supports higher wages and living standards.

charts.title: CPI Inflation Rate
charts.subtitle: Year-over-year change, percent
charts.description: The Consumer Price Index measures the average change in prices paid by urban consumers for a basket of goods and services. This chart shows the year-over-year percent change.

charts.title: Trade Balance
charts.subtitle: Goods and services, share of GDP, percent
charts.description: The trade balance is exports minus imports of goods and services, shown here as a share of GDP. A negative value indicates a trade deficit.

charts.title: Tariff Rate
charts.subtitle: Tariff revenue as share of goods imports, percent
charts.description: The effective tariff rate is calculated as customs duties collected divided by the value of goods imports. It reflects the average tax rate on imported goods.

charts.title: Employment Rate
charts.subtitle: Employed share, age 25 to 54, percent
charts.description: The employment-population ratio shows the share of prime-age adults (25–54) who are employed. It is a broad measure of labor market health that is not affected by changes in labor force participation.

charts.title: Industrial Production
charts.subtitle: Manufacturing output, index, 2012 = 100
charts.description: The industrial production index measures the real output of the manufacturing sector. It is published by the Federal Reserve and indexed to 2012.

charts.title: Unemployment Rate
charts.subtitle: Unemployed share of labor force, percent
charts.description: The unemployment rate is the share of the labor force that is actively seeking work but unable to find a job. It is one of the most widely followed indicators of labor market conditions.

charts.title: Job Openings
charts.subtitle: Job openings per unemployed person
charts.description: This ratio divides the number of job openings (from the JOLTS survey) by the number of unemployed persons. A higher ratio indicates a tighter labor market with more opportunities per job seeker.

charts.title: Weekly Earnings, 10th Percentile
charts.subtitle: Full-time workers, inflation-adjusted USD
charts.description: Real weekly earnings at the 10th percentile of full-time workers, adjusted for inflation. This tracks wage growth for lower-paid workers using Current Population Survey microdata.

charts.title: Federal Receipts
charts.subtitle: Total receipts, trailing 12 months, percent of GDP
charts.description: Total federal government receipts (taxes, fees, and other revenue) over a trailing 12-month period, expressed as a share of GDP. This smooths seasonal variation in tax collections.

charts.title: Poverty Rate, Selected Countries
charts.subtitle: Share of population below 50% of median income
charts.description: The relative poverty rate measures the share of population living below 50% of the national median disposable income. It allows cross-country comparison of income adequacy.

charts.title: House Price Index
charts.subtitle: Index, 1991 = 100
charts.description: The FHFA House Price Index tracks changes in single-family home prices based on repeat sales data from mortgages purchased or guaranteed by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

charts.title: Inflation Contributions
charts.subtitle: Contribution to year-over-year CPI, percentage points
charts.description: This chart decomposes the Consumer Price Index into contributions by category, showing which goods and services are driving inflation up or down the most.

charts.title: Government Spending
charts.subtitle: General government spending, percent of GDP
charts.description: Total general government expenditure (federal, state, and local) as a share of GDP. This includes spending on social programs, defense, infrastructure, and public services.

charts.title: Output and Wages
charts.subtitle: Inflation-adjusted USD, in thousands
charts.description: This chart compares inflation-adjusted GDP per worker with median earnings (annualized from usual weekly earnings), both in thousands of dollars. The gap between the two lines reflects how broadly economic gains are shared.

charts.title: Corporate Profits
charts.subtitle: Share of net national income, percent
charts.description: Corporate profits as a share of net national income, measuring the portion of total economic output that accrues to businesses after production costs and depreciation.

charts.title: Business Investment
charts.subtitle: Net fixed investment, percent of GDP
charts.description: Private nonresidential fixed investment minus depreciation, as a share of GDP. This measures net additions to the economy's productive capital stock, including equipment, structures, and intellectual property.
